title: Dismantling the PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals’ Legacy [Sponsored]
intro: More sustainable ways of removing persistent chemicals known as per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from the environment are on the horizon.

transcript.author: ​​Megan Hall
transcript.text: They're in your shampoo, your carpet, your non-stick pan, and your fast food wrapper. They've also been found at the top of Mount Everest. This group of manufactured chemicals called PFAS are pretty much everywhere you look, and high exposures to them might increase the risk of everything from some cancers to infertility. What do we do about these so-called forever chemicals? Scientific American Custom Media recently sat down with David Trueba, the President and Chief Executive Officer of Revive Environmental, to learn more about the problem and some possible solutions.

transcript.author: ​​Megan Hall
transcript.text: David Trueba fell in love with chemistry when he was a junior in high school.

transcript.author: David Trueba
transcript.text: I was fortunate to have Mrs. Travers as my chemistry teacher.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: He says Mrs. Travers got him hooked on combining substances to create new ones and solve problems.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: And she actually worked for the EPA, funny enough.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: So as a chemist, he actually has a deep respect for the chemicals that include the coating we use for non-stick pans.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: I honestly think Teflon as a story is really cool. It was happened upon by accident. It's completely effective.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: What started as products like Teflon in the late 1930s is now a group of more than 9,000 chemicals called PFAS or per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: And their purpose is to fight fires and prevent things from sticking and to help in production of many of the products that we really take for granted as a society globally.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: In part, these PFAS are effective because their chemical bonds are incredibly strong.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: That's why they're called forever chemicals. They were designed to be indestructible. The elegance of the chemistry is that they stick around forever and they can be applied to many surfaces. Once cured, they don't move. The problem is that they last forever.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: And they have some serious potential health consequences.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: So there's real issues with prolonged exposure. Cancer, reproductive issues, growth and deformities, birth defects. These are real situations that people have experienced in the last probably 30 years, plus.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: So what do you do with harmful indestructible chemicals that are found in hundreds of products? Many consumers use activated carbon filters to strain PFAS out of our water.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Think of a Brita water filter. It's capturing contaminants, keeping your water odor and taste positive, etc.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: But eventually those carbon sponges, which are made of materials like wood, coconut shells, coal or peat, reach their capacity and have to get thrown out. David says they're then sent to landfills, buried deep underground or burned in an incinerator. But that doesn't get rid of the PFAS.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: You're moving the problem from the source to a place where it's going to go back in the environment.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: Remember, these are forever chemicals. They're still soaked into the sponges. There's even debate about whether burning them is effective.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: There's a lot of science right now on incineration. I won't speak for the incineration industry. What I can tell you is that there was PFAS rain that came from the air in the summer of 2021.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: That can't be good. So scientists and engineers started working on another approach.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Battelle Memorial Institute, our founding company, they saw PFAS as a challenge five years ago and they chartered a group of the best scientists in the world to come up with a suite of how do you deal with PFAS.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: They designed a process that uses extreme heat and energy to treat PFAS-contaminated water.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Our reactors go above 374 degrees Celsius and over 3,000 PSI. That's a lot of pressure. It creates what's called supercritical water.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: When water is in that supercritical state, it's both a liquid and a gas. That gives it unique powers.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: It fully dissolves oxygen from the air, and any solvent or any ion can be dissolved fully.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David says that dissolved oxygen attaches to the PFAS and breaks it.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: So dirty black water goes in and clean water comes out. And there's only two by-products. It's clean water and salt.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: They decided to call the closed system that makes this possible the PFAS Annihilator.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: I think it's an apt name because annihilation is really what happens. There's no trace of that PFAS molecule left.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: Other companies use the same approach to destroy PFAS or treat toxic sludge, but David says the Annihilator is faster.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Some technologies take hours to do this. We do it in less than 10 seconds.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: And David says the Annihilator is already being used in the field, treating PFAS-contaminated liquid 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Revive just launched our first commercial-scale unit to the State of Michigan, and we're live. We're producing right now, PFAS destruction.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: The company also has a product to treat those carbon sponges that filter PFAS out of the water. David says it can...

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Extract the PFAS off the carbon, leave the carbon there, and make the carbon more effective for PFAS capture. And we all do that for less money than it costs to discharge and dispose the carbon, and it lasts four times longer.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David is optimistic about his company's efforts to treat PFAS. Over the next two years, he hopes to deliver 25 PFAS Annihilators to spots around North America. But he says there's a lot more work to be done.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: First of all, there's a real need to look at our infrastructure, why we use PFAS today, and to replace materials.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: Because if industry stopped using PFAS in their products, there'd be less of a need to clean them up. But to do that, we'd need something to replace them.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Just PFAS replacement as a goal is a scientific opportunity that's really exciting.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David says the scientific community could also help with another PFAS challenge. The chemicals are hard to detect in low concentrations.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: The health advisory limits are in the part per quadrillion. One part per trillion, just to give you a flavor of the scope, it is a single drop of water in an Olympic-sized swimming pool. Part per quadrillion is one thousandth of that. We can't detect below part per trillion today.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David also welcomes help in his area of expertise, removing PFAS from the environment.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: How do you deal with a PFAS that's already here? And whether that's soil extraction or remediation, taking care of drinking water at source, or eliminating the challenge of recycle, these are all opportunities that we can get around, extracting, removing and eliminating PFAS from the community.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David says he's still in awe of PFAS. They're a marvel of chemistry, though it turns out that being virtually indestructible does come with drawbacks.

transcript.author: Trueba
transcript.text: Innovation today might be a challenge tomorrow. We do the best that we can with what we know.

transcript.author: Hall
transcript.text: David says he's inspired to stand on the shoulders of a scientist who developed PFAS to address the challenges they created. It's what his chemistry teacher, Mrs. Travers, would've wanted. David Trueba is the President and CEO of Revive Environmental. Revive Environmental is a full-service environmental contaminant mitigation company on a mission to rid America of water contaminated by PFAS.
